Award.AwardTitle: CGV: Small: Collaborative Research: Theories, algorithms, and applications of medial forms for shape analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Shape analysis is a fundamental problem in computer graphics and vision. A significant body of research over the past few decades has centered around the medial axis, a classical geometric structure introduced by Blum in 1967. Not only does the medial axis provide a low-dimensional representation that captures both the shape and topology of the object, it also creates derivative shape descriptors that measure useful shape properties, such as thickness. This collaborative project that involves two partner institutions builds on that body of research and extends it in two important and related directions. First, the PIs will generalize the definition of medial axis to systemically define a sequence of medial representations of successively lower dimensionality (e.g., medial curve and medial point of a 3D object) that all inherit the essential properties of the medial axis. These representations, called medial forms, are useful in various applications such as shape matching and decomposition. While algorithms for computing low-dimensional skeletal structures are abundant, sound mathematical definitions have not yet been developed. Second, based on the medial forms, the PIs will introduce a set of shape descriptors that can characterize non-uniform (or anisotropic) expansion of shape. These descriptors will not only be able to differentiate plate-like and tubular parts, but also to measure the amount of plate-like stretching and tube-like elongation. Shape anisotropy is common in 3D objects, and is important for deriving knowledge from digital models, particularly in biological research. However, none of the existing descriptors can characterize this important aspect of 3D shape. The PIs will build on their recent study of 2D objects to develop the mathematical foundation and computational algorithms of medial forms of 3D objects, and will explore their use in analyzing shape anisotropy through several derivative shape descriptors. They will formalize the definitions of medial forms of a 3D object, and will examine their properties including their dimensionality, topology, and sensitivity to boundary perturbations. Based on the definitions, the PIs will develop efficient algorithms that create provably good approximations of the medial forms given discrete samples of an object. The PIs will explore how a variety of derivative anisotropy-aware descriptors, in the forms of either geometric skeletons or surface signature functions, complement existing descriptors in shape modeling applications (e.g., segmentation and matching) and in biological shape analysis.

Broader Impacts: The new mathematical formulations and shape descriptors will contribute significantly to both the theoretical and applied side of computer graphics. The ability to characterize shape anisotropy will directly translate to more accurate and efficient analysis of shapes in various application domains, and the PIs will particularly explore their use in understanding biological shapes. The team will develop and distributable online software that implements the new algorithms. Students, both at the undergraduate and graduate level, will be actively recruited with an emphasis on diversity, and in addition project outcomes will be used in outreach programs at local middle- and high-schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Shape is a fundamental concept when interacting with the world; while humans are remarkably good at classifying and comparing shapes, it remains challenging for computers to do the same tasks even on very simple examples.  However, it is critical that computers be able to recognize shapes, since it is a key step when analyzing real world data.  For example, when studying aneurysms, better treatments options can be developed if the software has an understand of the underlying shape of the aneurysm.  Another example comes from plant biology, where in order to do genetic analysis to breed in desirable traits such as large leaves and drought tolerant roots, the software must be able to somehow quantify these aspects of the plant’s shape.  

 

In this collaborative project between researchers at Washington University in St. Louis and St. Louis University, the team has developed new shape analysis tools based on the medial axis, a structure that has been widely used to give simpler representations of an object that nonetheless capture key shape features.  We developed computer programs to calculate these objects, established theoretical guarantees about the quality of our results, and worked with domain experts in various disciplines to generate better automated shape detection, recognition, and classification algorithms. Some of the notable outcomes are:

 

- We proposed novel definitions of medial structures (e.g., medial curves, medial points) as well as shape metrics (which we call burn time), and we analyzed their mathematical properties. These structures metrics quantitatively describe the decomposition of the shape into parts as well as high-level shape properties such as tubularity and elongation.

 

- We developed robust and efficient algorithms for computing these structures and metrics for complex 3D shapes.

 

- We have explored a suite of applications, particularly in biology and medicine, that use the computed medial structures and metrics for quantifying shapes of digital models, as well as using such quantification to answer domain-specific questions.

 

The outcome of our has significant impact both within computer science and in other disciplines. Within computer science,  our research allows one to mathematically and computationally characterize aspects of 3D shapes that cannot be captured by prior state-of-the-art methods. Beyond computer science, the new and better descriptors produced by our research would translate to improved accuracy and/or efficiency in many imaging-centered applications which routinely inquire the shape of digital models.

 

The research has produced more than ten peer-reviewed publications in top venues in both computer graphics (e.g.,  ACM Transactions on Graphics and IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Graphics) and application domains (e.g., International Symposium on Biomedical Imaging and Biophysical Journal). The PIs have presented talks in conferences and invited venues, and they organized a workshop on the topic of medial axis. The tools are distributed freely online. The project has provided training for four graduate students across the two institutions.
